object.content: How DIY Projects Inspire Kids I like what + Isaiah Saxon  and his crew at DIY are doing with their NEXT LEVEL series on YouTube. They take kids' DIY fantasies and help them take them to the next level, showing up, helping with the project, and making a short film about it. When I was a kid, I used to get the Edmund Scientific Catalog a couple of times a year, and pore over it, imagining what I could build.  "These electromagnets - why they say they support 100 pounds each! And they are only six inches long!  I could make special electromagnetic boots, so I could walk up the sides of steel buildings!" Or seeing some sheet metal that my friend Bill's dad, a contractor, had on hand - "we could weld this into a submarine!"  But we didn't know enough to know how to think about actually tackling these projects.  The YouTube.com/DIYTV channel is all about this - showing off what kids are doing - but this new show is about how they can take it to the next level.﻿

title: +Clay Shirky always has the most insightful and colorfully told take on the intersection of technology...

attachments.content: Back in the mid-1990s, I did a lot of web work for traditional media. That often meant figuring out what the client was already doing on the web, and how it was going, so I'd find the techies in the company, and ask them what they were doing, and how it was going. Then I'd tell management what ...
attachments.displayName: » Healthcare.gov and the Gulf Between Planning and Reality Clay Shirky

object.content: + Clay Shirky  always has the most insightful and colorfully told take on the intersection of technology, culture, and management.  His essay on the failure of healthcare.gov is no exception.  It should be required reading for anyone managing projects in a large organization.  One excerpt: "This is not just a hiring problem, or a procurement problem. This is a management problem, and a cultural problem. The preferred method for implementing large technology projects in Washington is to write the plans up front, break them into increasingly detailed specifications, then build what the specifications call for. It’s often called the waterfall method, because on a timeline the project cascades from planning, at the top left of the chart, down to implementation, on the bottom right. "Like all organizational models, waterfall is mainly a theory of collaboration. By putting the most serious planning at the beginning, with subsequent work derived from the plan, the waterfall method amounts to a pledge by all parties not to learn anything while doing the actual work. Instead, waterfall insists that the participants will understand best how things should work before accumulating any real-world experience, and that planners will always know more than workers. "This is a perfect fit for a culture that communicates in the deontic language of legislation. It is also a dreadful way to make new technology. If there is no room for learning by doing, early mistakes will resist correction. If the people with real technical knowledge can’t deliver bad news up the chain, potential failures get embedded rather than uprooted as the work goes on."﻿

title:
Why Government Investment Makes Sense Now

I was interested to see what appears to be a Libertarian-...

attachments.displayName: On Depressions, the Structure of Production & Fiscal Policy
attachments.content: I came into economics and finance blogging in 2011 a very different economic thinker than I am today. I was convinced (and remain convinced) that we were going through a once-in a generation economic transformation, or more a...

object.content: Why Government Investment Makes Sense Now I was interested to see what appears to be a Libertarian-leaning author making the case for government spending in the face of the current worldwide economic situation.  Frankly, I wish the US and Europe were investing a lot more in infrastructure right now, and putting idle resources to work on stuff that matters while credit is still cheap.  We'll still have to do that stuff later on, when it will be more expensive, because by then the government will be competing with the private sector for resources. From the article: "Governments particularly in Britain and the Eurozone have attempted to fight depressed growth using austerity policies (in the context of expansionary monetary policy). The proponents of austerity theorise that by promising to bring down taxes and spending, they will unleash private sector spending by reducing future expectations of taxes. To me, this has always seemed like a boneheaded and Rube Goldberg-style approach. Simply, the issue of depressed private economic activity is far more complex than future taxation expectations. And aggressive monetary policy has not succeeded in reversing the depression (even if it has probably made the depression less severe). So it has been entirely unsurprising to me to see this approach largely failing. I approach the problem in a far more direct manner. The solution to lowered growth and elevated (and involuntary) unemployment is relatively simple.Eventually someone will start using up the idle resources. This will either be the private sector once it independently gets over its slump in animal spirits, or it will be the government. With such huge volumes of idle capital, interest rates will remain very low until stronger appetite for credit re-emerges. In equilibrium theory, the low cost of credit will by itself start to re-energise borrowing appetite by making more projects potentially profitable. Of course, interest rates are far from the only factor that borrowers take into account when seeking credit, and so it is perfectly plausible that the economy — as it has done — can remain depressed even with very low rates due to deleveraging pressures, low expectations and low confidence, etc. So if the market is ill-suited to taking up the idle resources any time soon — lying as it is in a depressive, irrational strop — the only agent that can do so is the state. The fact of low interest rates allows this to kill two birds with one stone — the state can borrow money (utilising idle capital) to create jobs (utilising idle labour), raising interest rates and bringing down the unemployment rate. And this approach does not require anyone to make accurate predictions about the future. It simply requires a market economy, and a state willing to employ idle resources when they are idle, and to ease off using idle resources when unemployment becomes low and interest rates start to rise. "Many — including probably Hayek himself — would argue that using up idle resources in such a manner will not allow the structure of production to adjust to the new economic reality. The state, Hayek would argue is a poor allocator of capital because it lacks the informational efficiency of the market. I would mostly agree with Hayek’s objection, and note that I favour a predominantly market-based economy. Government interventions should be kept to a necessary minimum. Yet, in a depressionary environment, the structure of production deteriorates as resources lie idle. Unemployed workers lose skills, lose competitive edge and spend and invest less, further depressing the economy. Capital — factories, buildings, amenities, ideas, etc — deteriorates. Young workers may enter the labour force but never find a job. Crime rises, and shady fringe businesses like loan sharks thrive as the unemployed struggle to pay the bills. The social costs of mass unemployment are exceedingly high. The adjustment occurring in a depression is more like a rot. And it is absurd to rot your way to growth. Instead, by lowering unemployment and using up idle capital (preferably in a mix of state-run infrastructure and technology projects, and lending to new businesses) more businesses can be born into existence. Potentially successful new ideas can be tried out, and may find success in the marketplace. The formerly unemployed get to develop skills, habits and ideas, instead of sitting at home all day doing nothing, or hunting for jobs in a scarce and depressed marketplace. And money will go into people’s pockets, spurring investment and consumption, fomenting more new business growth. This, in my view, is the best shot at getting a depressed and rotten structure of production out of the doldrums and back toward strong organic growth. Sooner or later, of course, the private sector will come back and begin to use up resources. But that could be a very, very, very long way away. If we want the structure of production to adjust to the new world and to continue adjusting as the world continues to change, letting huge quantities of resources sitting idle seems like a bad way to do it. Targeted fiscal policy can change that.﻿

title: The Guardian just published Nobel Prize-winning poet Seamus Heaney's last known poem, "In a Field", ...

attachments.displayName: New Seamus Heaney poem published
attachments.content: Guardian publishes In a Field ahead of its appearance in anthology marking centenary of outbreak of first world war • The War Poets Revisited – interactive anthology

object.content: The Guardian just published Nobel Prize-winning poet Seamus Heaney's last known poem, "In a Field", which he wrote for an anthology to be published next year in commemoration of the one-hundredth anniversary of World War I. In the anthology, contemporary authors were asked to reflect on documents from the time. Heaney chose a poem by British poet Edward Thomas, "As the Team's Head Brass," which is also reproduced in the article. It is even more poignant than Heaney's commemoration of it.  Through a conversation with a farmer plowing a field, Thomas' poem reflects on the emptiness of Britain, whose men went off to war and never came back.  Thomas himself joined their ranks shortly after writing his poem, and died in France the following year. The poems  reminded me of the plaque on one of the columns in Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris that never fails to bring tears to my eyes when I visit it.  It reads: TO THE MEMORY OF ONE MILLION MEN OF THE BRITISH EMPIRE WHO FELL IN THE GREAT WAR 1914-1918, AND OF WHOM THE GREATER PART REST IN FRANCE One million men!  And that's just the Brits, Australians, Canadians, New Zealanders, South Africans, Indians, and others from the British Empire.  Never mind the French, the Germans, and (in World War II, even more destructive though less pointless, the Jews, the Russians, and the Poles). It is good to remember that tumultuous time, and to reflect on how easy it is for things to go awry, for the human world to spin out of control into darkness.  But even more important, we can use this opportunity to reflect on how little we have been asked to spend of our courage, our passion, and our lives confronting the great issues of our day.﻿

title:
Ireland's School of Falconry

One of the highlights of my family trip to Ireland in May was a visit ...

object.content: Ireland's School of Falconry One of the highlights of my family trip to Ireland in May was a visit to Ireland's School of Falconry at Ashford Castle in County Mayo ( http://www.falconry.ie/ ). We took a group lesson - with an age range from four to 86 - and as you can see, a splendid time was had by all. Our instructor and guide, Aurelia, was knowledgeable, patient, and a great teacher. What was most astonishing to me is how lightly a falcon lands on your wrist. It's like a breath of air, so light and controlled that if your eyes were closed, you might not be sure it had happened. My pictures were mediocre, and so I didn't bother sharing them. These, which I just got from my fellow grandparents, Australian painter Pamela Griffith ( http://www.pamelagriffith.com/ ) and her husband Ross, are magnificent, and give a sense of what it's like. Be sure to see the picture of my grandson eye-to-eye with a falcon!﻿

Jim Parrack was a perennial highlight of mine on True Blood, where he played golden-hearted good old boy Hoyt, and Franco's use of him here is absolute genius. He brings naturalism and genuine soulfulness to his portrayal of oldest brother Cash. Logan Marshall-Green is the handsome guy from Prometheus, but he'll always be Ryan's bad news brother Trey Atwood from The O.C. to me. He made me forget about Trey in this movie by sporting a beard and a sometimes indecipherable accent and reminding me of Heath Ledger in Brokeback Mountain."﻿

How Beautiful Interfaces Create Trust and Loyalty

Reading Farhad Manjoo's recent article about Google's...

attachments.displayName: How Google Taught Itself Good Design
attachments.content: Long dominant in online search advertising and maps Google has shifted gears from utility to beauty--and is now more fearsome than ever.

object.content: How Beautiful Interfaces Create Trust and Loyalty Reading Farhad Manjoo's recent article about Google's new commitment to design and the difference it is making, I was struck by the word "beauty."  Steve Jobs' success at Apple made the word a key part of the strategic business lexicon, and now Google is executing on the beauty game plan. Government needs to learn the same lesson. In particular, I was struck by the parallels between Larry Page's pursuit of beauty in Google products and White House Deputy CTO Jennifer Pahlka's assertion that one of the best ways to restore faith in government is to create interfaces to government services that are simple, beautiful, and easy to use. (Jen is also the founder of Code for America.) From POLITICO's profile of Jen when she went to work for the the White House: "Jennifer Pahlka thinks of a good government website as nothing less than a way to improve democracy. If the site is 'simple, beautiful and easy to use, you feel differently about government'" ( http://www.politico.com/story/2013/07/50-politicos-to-watch-jennifer-pahlka-94195.html#ixzz2g6FkSUcD ) From Manjoo's article: "With the rise of sleek, portable touch-screen computers--i.e., the rise of Apple--people were now interacting with software in the same hands-on way they do with cars, clothes, appliances, and other physical goods. "Our expectations of the real world began transferring to the virtual world," [lead designer for Google Search, Jon] Wiley says. Google's designers needed to address questions that they'd scarcely considered before: How do you feel when you use the product? Is it friendly, exciting, disorienting? Is it beautiful? "The evidence suggested they weren't meeting those goals. In 2010, Google conducted a series of user tests to find out how people felt about Android. The results were stark: 'A lot of people felt that Android was essential to their lives, but they didn't like Android,' [Android Design Director Matias] Duarte says. The robust abilities of the OS 'made them feel small. It wasn't empowering, but daunting.' The same could be said for other Google products. When you loaded up something made by Google, you were more likely to feel overwhelmed than welcomed. "Page took the two goals, beauty and cohesiveness, and combined them into a single mandate for designers: He called it 'One Beautiful Google.'" And the results speak for themselves.   I've often heard a similar notion from Jen -- that contemporary technology has raised the bar for government. When people can get information instantly on their smartphone, when companies like Amazon can have a product on your doorstep in less than a day, when these services are not only powerful but simple, beautiful, and easy to use, government looks even more like a bad bargain. If Barack Obama really wants to restore faith in government, and change the poisonous dialogue in Washington, he could do worse than pay attention to what Larry Page has done at Google, putting beauty and simplicity in government services at the heart of the legacy that his administration will leave the American people. Again, from Manjoo's article: "While Page has never suggested a single design element, he was crucial to the redesign for the simple reason that he made it a firmwide priority. 'Only the CEO can get the entire company to focus on something,' says Wiley." Disclosure: Jen Pahlka is my fiancé, and I am on the board of Code for America.﻿

object.content: I wrote a post on LinkedIn the other day to explain the provocative title of my talk at the new + O'Reilly  Cultivate Conference ( http://cultivatecon.com/cultivate2013 ).  The talk is entitled "How I Failed."  It's a retrospective on the things I didn't do as well as I could have in terms of institutionalizing all the right best practices as we built O'Reilly (as brought home to us forcefully by the 2001 dot com bust), and by implication, a look at what we have been doing over the past decade or so to fix them. It's long, but seems to have hit a very positive nerve with a lot of people.﻿

title: There's a lot of truth to this new piece by Nick Hanauer and Eric Liu, comparing the idealized libertarian...

attachments.displayName: Libertarians Are the New Communists
attachments.content: Most people would consider radical libertarianism and communism polar opposites: The first glorifies personal freedom. The second would obliterate it. Yet the ideologies are simply mirror images. Both attempt to answer the same questions, and fail to do so in similar ways. Where communism was adopted, the result was misery, poverty and tyranny. If extremist libertarians ever translated their beliefs into policy, it would lead to the same kinds of...

object.content: There's a lot of truth to this new piece by Nick Hanauer and Eric Liu, comparing the idealized libertarian state to the idealized communist state, and explaining why both fail in similar ways.  I know that this piece will draw a lot of flak - libertarians seem to be the most jealous of partisans, quick to criticize others but loath to consider criticism of their own views. But I think there is a lot of truth to it.  There is a lot of truth in the ideals that libertarians espouse, just as there is a lot of truth in the aspirations of communists, but they both do seem unaware of the difference between theory and practice, and unwilling to learn from experience.﻿

title:
What I don't like about my Tesla Model S

Everyone loves the Tesla Model S.  And I agree with most of...

object.content: What I don't like about my Tesla Model S Everyone loves the Tesla Model S.  And I agree with most of the hype. It’s a delightful car to drive, with a head-turning design, and all my worries about range have proven to be completely unnecessary.  (I do have the 85 battery.)  There are wonderful little grace notes, like the app that tracks the location of the car (which has already saved me once from losing my car in a vast airport parking lot, and let me decide that there was time to run back to the bathroom when being picked up at the airport.) The navigation system (with the tech package) is superb. I love that there’s a small “next turn” display right behind the steering wheel so you don’t have to look over at the main screen. And the audio volume even goes to 11! :-) But it’s not perfect. In the spirit of being helpful to the designers of future models, I thought I’d list some things that I find less than perfect.  In no particular order: * If the door isn’t completely shut, the car refuses to lock at all. This means that if your kid doesn’t shut the door hard enough, and you walk away without looking, your car remains unlocked. The first time this happened, my car was rifled through during the night, and anything moveable was taken. * The control panel is so big and lovely, with so many options, that it is really dangerous until you spend the time to learn where everything is. You don’t want to be looking for how to turn on the defroster when you are driving!  You need to figure out where all the commonly needed options are before you start.  Once you get used to it, it’s fine, but it’s a little alarming at first. Take the time to train your eye and hand! * The bluetooth is flaky. (What bluetooth isn’t?) At times, it works delightfully, automatically switching to my phone when I step into the car in the middle of a call. At worst, though, the entertainment system got totally wedged, thinking it was connected to Audible on my phone, and having that non-working display even overwrite maps and directions. I had to restart the display. (Hold down both buttons on the steering wheel till it reboots.) * The key, lovely as it is - an art object in itself - is designed in such a way that it’s impossible to put on a key-ring with other keys (except with a cord rather than a ring.) * There is no spare tire.  This is probably OK, but it worries me. And I didn't realize it till I got the car home. Tesla should do a better job of making this clear, and what to do if you have a flat. (The car can't be towed, has to go on a flatbed truck.) * Visibility out the back is mediocre. * It gets pretty hot in the way back for kids in the kid seats. (This is a known problem, and they’ve suggested workarounds.) * I miss the little sunglass holder up by the roof that was sported by our Prius. * I’d love if the back-up display drew lines (like in modern sports events) to show me the location of the sides of the car relative to the display. The wide-angle lens takes some getting used to, the car seems wider than I’m used to (not sure whether it is, but it feels that way) and I have a hard time telling how close the wheel is to the kerb or other obstacles. There are probably other things that nag me, but this list will do for now. Just a reminder that no one is perfect...﻿

title: Here's a slightly longer version of my maiden flight in a Warbird - Kevin Walker's L-39C Albatros, flying...

attachments.displayName: A Taste of a Fighter Jet
attachments.content: On August 31, 2013, I got a chance to ride in the back seat of Kevin Walker's L-39C Albatros fighter jet trainer, flying out of Hollister CA. Footage is a mi...

object.content: Here's a slightly longer version of my maiden flight in a Warbird - Kevin Walker's L-39C Albatros, flying out of Hollister CA on August 31, 2013. Footage is a mixture of backward and forward facing GoPro cameras (forward-facing culled from a video compilation Kevin sent me) with a touch of my Google Glass. Audio of Kevin's emergency instructions was from the pre-flight briefing, running through my mind as we did the slow roll (as that was what he said he would do if for any reason we had to eject.)  It was a blast!﻿
